title.narrative: Ouganda (l'): Aide ciblée aux pays
Uganda: Targeted country assistance

description.narrative:
Plans d’assistance technique ciblée aux pays L’assistance technique ciblée aux pays (TCA) est octroyée sous forme de ressources destinées aux partenaires présents dans les pays. La TCA est un élément du cadre d’engagement avec les partenaires (PEF) de Gavi. Le plan de TCA d’un pays est établie selon les besoins exprimés du dit pays lors de l’évaluation conjointe. Un plan comprend une liste d’activités, d’étapes clés, et un budget pour une année dite. L’assistance technique est un soutien non financier fourni par des spécialistes. Elle peut revêtir plusieurs formes : partage d’information et de savoir-faire, formation et services-conseils.
L’assistance technique fournie dans le cadre du PEF est appelée aide ciblée aux pays. Ce type de soutien vise principalement à payer le personnel basé en permanence dans les bureaux pays des partenaires. Il repose sur la demande et les besoins identifiés par les pays eux-mêmes.

Targeted country assistance (TCA) are resources provided to in-country partners under Gavi’s partners’ engagement framework (PEF). A country’s TCA plan is based on needs expressed by the country during the joint appraisal discussions. It includes sets of activities, milestones and budget for a given year.Technical assistance is non-financial support provided by specialists. It can take the form of sharing information and expertise, training and consulting services.
The technical assistance provided through PEF is called targeted country assistance (TCA). This type of support mainly consists of staff permanently based in partners’ country offices. It is based on the demand and needs identified by the countries themselves.

title.narrative: Partners' engagement framework

description.narrative: Through the partners’ engagement framework, Vaccine Alliance partners support countries’ immunisation activities

condition.narrative: Conditions are detailed in the Partners’ engagement framework
Les conditions sont détaillées dans le cadre d'engagement des partenaires

title.narrative: UNICEF : Vaccine-Specific Support
SOP/guidelines for immunization waste disposal available and in use

target.value: Work with UNEPI and NMS to develop SOPs/guidelines for Sustainable waste management of used immunisation waste and implementation of the plan. The activity implementaton will mainly cater for transport from districts to disposal sites.

comment.narrative: Development of the Medical Waste Disposal was overtaken by events. PATH supported a consultant who worked with partners to develop the guidelines which are ready and have been submitted to MOH for approval. UNICEF will use this budget line to print and distribute as soon as final approvals are made.

target.value: Work with UNEPI and NMS to develop SOPs/guidelines for Sustainable waste management of used immunisation waste and implementation of the plan. The activity implementaton will mainly cater for transport from districts to disposal sites.

comment.narrative: Development of the Medical Waste Disposal was overtaken by events. PATH supported a consultant who worked with partners to develop the guidelines which are ready and have been submitted to MOH for approval. UNICEF will use this budget line to print and distribute as soon as final approvals are made.

title.narrative: WHO
50% of districts to have capacity built for health workers and caregivers on importance of card retention, catch up vaccination & vaccines being delivered in the 2YL

target.value: Establish and strengthen the second year of life (2YL) immunization platform for introduction of vaccines in the second year of life (MR and booster doses)

comment.narrative: A focal point for 2YL platform at MOH has been identified; discussions have commenced to strategize implementation modalities;

title.narrative: 10 districts and over 200 health facilities with a functional eChild register submitting their Immunization facility data including vaccines management

target.value: Establishing of ehealth system- eChild register

comment.narrative: Discussions have commenced at country level to discuss modalities of implementation; however funds for this activity have not yet been disbursed to the country. These are part of TCA 2021

title.narrative: 70 districts and over 1,500 health facilities with a functional eChild register submitting their Immunization facility data including vaccines management.

target.value: Establishing of ehealth system- eChild register

comment.narrative: The allocated funds were grossly inadequate and hence were reprogrammed towards MOV. However resource mobilization is ongoing; lessons from the 10 districts planned to be implemented during TCA 2021 will inform next steps for other set of districts; COVID-19 vaccine roll out is another added advantage where DHIS2 and e register have been used that will also build a platform for routine immunization

title.narrative: WHO : Health Financing/Sustainability
Activities/considerations to strengthen programmatic/financial sustainability integrated/reflected in FPP outputs

target.value: Develop a financial sustainability plan for New Vaccine Introduction - engage a national local consultant to undertake the activity - Consultant engage different stakeholders including desk review to gather information - Final plan developed and disseminated to stakeholders including parliamentarian committee responsible for health

comment.narrative: A local consultant has been identified working closely with an international consultant virtually to conduct an investment case for RI; The overall aim of an investment case assessment is to define the costs of inaction or the status quo response, to identify priority areas of action, and quantify the benefits of these actions.

title.narrative: Near Final investment case for routine immunization and new vaccine introduction disseminated to policy makers

target.value: Develop and present an investment case for vaccines for RI and new vaccine introductions (such as Men-A and 2nd dose MR, booster Td dose), I) Engage the School of Public health (Mak SPH) to conduct operational research to identify operational barriers including GDP and per capita income to delivery of immunization services II) Provide technical support to MoH to monitor the roadmap for implementation of Addis Declaration on immunization

comment.narrative: Consultant hired; data collection has commenced; progress concept note on methodology shared; anticipate to be completed by end quarter 3 of 2021

title.narrative: An annual/rolling operational plan for immunisation developed by MOH/EPI (country-led, with capacity building component)

target.value: Support dissemination and utilization of the District Immunization Expenditure Resource Tracking Tool (DIET) in all districts -Engage a consultant who developed the tool in close collaboration with MOH /NEPI planning department to upload the tool on the DHIS2 platform - Develop a national roll out plan of DIET - Build capacity of national level users - Build capacity of district users (CAO, CFO, DH financing officer, DHO, ADHO, Biost etc) - Monitor utilization of the tool and ensure that data generated is used for JRF

comment.narrative: Due to competing activities this has been reprogrammed to next year

title.narrative: Roles and responsibilities for planning and budgeting for immunisation among all stakeholders involved mapped and agreed

target.value: Support dissemination and utilization of the District Immunization Expenditure Resource Tracking Tool (DIET) in all districts -Engage a consultant who developed the tool in close collaboration with MOH /NEPI planning department to upload the tool on the DHIS2 platform - Develop a national roll out plan of DIET - Build capacity of national level users - Build capacity of district users (CAO, CFO, DH financing officer, DHO, ADHO, Biost etc) - Monitor utilization of the tool and ensure that data generated is used for JRF

comment.narrative: The resource tracking system was developed and shared with MOH next steps is to engage HMIS division to design ways of uploading it onto the DHIS2 platform and hence roll it out to the districts; resource mobilization has to be done to support the roll out of the system

title.narrative: Identified activities/considerations to strengthen programmatic/financial sustainability integrated/reflected in the immunisation and health strategic and planning documents

target.value: Develop a financial sustainability plan for New Vaccine Introduction - engage a national local consultant to undertake the activity - Consultant engage different stakeholders including desk review to gather information - Final plan developed and disseminated to stakeholders including parliamentarian committee responsible for health

comment.narrative: The update is that a concept note was developed and shared with the IVD cluster. The next steps are to advertise the consultancy and engage the best selected candidate. This has been initiated

title.narrative: UNICEF : Programme Implementation/Coverage & Equity
Proportion of private health facilities in Jinja, Kampala, Wakiso and Iganga conducting immunization services and timely reporting through appropriate channels

target.value: Support the capacity strengthening, regulation, monitoring and supervision of the private health care facilities providing immunization services in the Urban settings (Wakiso, Iganga, Kampala and Jinja). 1) Carry out capacity building and review of the private health care facilities including the data management and compliance with Uganda's immunization guideline; 2) quarterly follow up, oversight and review

comment.narrative: During 2021, focus has been on ensuring continuity of essential health services in the urban setting, support was provided in (i) Vaccine distribution in the districts of KCCA and Wakiso to improve access to immunisation services (ii) Support to immunisation microplanning and coordination (iii) support to functionalize static and outreach services. Due to COVID-19 pandemic there has been a delay in engaging Uganda Pediatric Association to conduct private health facility capacity building and review. This is planned in third quarter of 2021. UNICEF Uganda has initiated a process to engage Uganda Pediatric Association (UPA) to support at national and district level with a special focus on urban districts to address immunisation inequities The expected outputs include strengthened capacity of Regional Referral Hospital Community Health Departments to plan and implement ACSM interventions to promote routine immunisation; institute regional champions and decision makers to advocate for and promote Routine immunisation; and sensitizing and supporting members of Uganda Medical Association, Uganda Pediatric Association, Uganda Nurses, Midwife and Public Health cadres and associations to actively get involved in media and community mobilisation efforts for routine immunisation (linked to supporting Urban Immunisation). Progress made to date to engage UPA include the development and discussion of the TOR and the activities to be implemented with the related budgets. All required documentation is almost complete waiting for the easing of the lockdown before funds are released.

title.narrative: [BLANK]

comment.narrative: During 2021, focus has been on ensuring continuity of essential health services in the urban setting, support was provided in (i) Vaccine distribution in the districts of KCCA and Wakiso to improve access to immunisation services (ii) Support to immunisation microplanning and coordination (iii) support to functionalize static and outreach services. Due to COVID-19 pandemic there has been a delay in engaging Uganda Pediatric Association to conduct private health facility capacity building and review. This is planned in third quarter of 2021. UNICEF Uganda has initiated a process to engage Uganda Pediatric Association (UPA) to support at national and district level with a special focus on urban districts to address immunisation inequities The expected outputs include strengthened capacity of Regional Referral Hospital Community Health Departments to plan and implement ACSM interventions to promote routine immunisation; institute regional champions and decision makers to advocate for and promote Routine immunisation; and sensitizing and supporting members of Uganda Medical Association, Uganda Pediatric Association, Uganda Nurses, Midwife and Public Health cadres and associations to actively get involved in media and community mobilisation efforts for routine immunisation (linked to supporting Urban Immunisation).

During 2021, focus has been on ensuring continuity of essential health services in the urban setting, support was provided in (i) Vaccine distribution in the districts of KCCA and Wakiso to improve access to immunisation services (ii) Support to immunisation microplanning and coordination (iii) support to functionalize static and outreach services. Due to COVID-19 pandemic there has been a delay in engaging Uganda Pediatric Association to conduct private health facility capacity building and review. This is planned in third quarter of 2021. UNICEF Uganda has initiated a process to engage Uganda Pediatric Association (UPA) to support at national and district level with a special focus on urban districts to address immunisation inequities The expected outputs include strengthened capacity of Regional Referral Hospital Community Health Departments to plan and implement ACSM interventions to promote routine immunisation; institute regional champions and decision makers to advocate for and promote Routine immunisation; and sensitizing and supporting members of Uganda Medical Association, Uganda Pediatric Association, Uganda Nurses, Midwife and Public Health cadres and associations to actively get involved in media and community mobilisation efforts for routine immunisation (linked to supporting Urban Immunisation).

target.value: Support the capacity strengthening, regulation, monitoring and supervision of the private health care facilities providing immunization services in the Urban settings (Wakiso, Iganga, Kampala and Jinja). 1) Carry out capacity building and review of the private health care facilities including the data management and compliance with Uganda's immunization guideline; 2) quarterly follow up, oversight and review

comment.narrative: The Urban Immunisation Communication Plan has been developed and finalized. A literature/desk review was conducted by the consultant followed by a Rapid Assessment on factors affecting demand for immunisation services in urban settings conducted in March 2021. The assessment was conducted in high densely populated urban settings of 7 districts of Kampala, Wakiso, Mukono, Jinja, Iganga, Gulu and Mbarara. A total of 17 urban settings in informal settlements and high-end social class communities in 7 districts were selected and covered during the rapid assessment. The consultant also caried out key informant interviews with key stakeholders including the Ministry of Health, Implementing partners, District, City and Municipal leaders. The key findings were used to inform the development of a draft Urban Immunisation Communication Plan. A review meeting was held on 14 July 2021 to review the Urban Immunisation Communication Plan followed by a consensus and validation meeting held on 29 July 2021.

title.narrative: Regional teams trained and available for supporting the EPI program to improve immunization services in the districts

target.value: Provide technical and financial support to 14 Regional referral hospital community health departements to conduct mentorship and supervision of the districts in the region. i) Identifying the regional teams 2)Building capacity in the regional teams to conduct supervision and on-job mentoring using ODK tool. 3) Technical support to poorly perfoming districts in the 14 regions

comment.narrative: In Uganda, provision of immunisation services is the mandate of local governments. Among the oversight and stewardship roles of MOH/UNEPI, support supervision and on job mentoring is key to ensure quality in health services delivery including immunization. However, due to the increasing numbers of districts, supervision of immunisation service delivery was identified as inadequate during the November 2019 Gavi JA. Each of the 14 Regional Referral Hospitals (RRH), has a Community Health Department (CHD) that by structure is expected to support selected number of districts. However, the RRH CHD have minimal resources including staffing and skill to effectively provide the support supervision role. The 2019 Gavi JA prioritized Gavi funding through PEF/ CA 2020 strengthening the capacity of the RRH CHDs to provide technical backstopping for Communicable & Vaccine Preventable Disease Control in districts. WHO, UNICEF, AFENET/CDC and USAID/MCHN worked together to ensure the proposed activities are synergistically implemented. A concept note, implementation plan and resource materials were developed, and consensus built under UNEPI leadership. UNICEF supported the national level training of 30 trainers and 8 RRH. In each of the 8 RRH, 30 officers referred to as Regional Immunisation Supervision and Mentorship team (RISMT) were trained and will be responsible for supporting 76 districts. The strategy of building RISMTs presents opportunity to leverage the already existing regional resource and government structures to strengthen and own Immunization. Financial support is required for the RISMT to conduct regular regional supportive supervision and monitoring in the catchment districts at least twice annually. The regional teams are being used by MoH to support other health service delivery. The teams have supported the Corvid 19 vaccine deployment.

title.narrative: WHO : Service Delivery
Roadmap for improved integration of EPI with other PHC services

target.value: Support reduction of zero dose and under immunized children by 20% in 15 rural districts with high numbers of zero dose - Engage HSIP to develop an e registry for routine immunization - Engage a CSO to undertake the district support - Identify districts through data analysis including triangulation for districts with >2000 zero dose children for past 3 years - Map the areas with high numbers - Develop an evidence based strategic plan to reach the children through consultative workshops at district level - Support districts to deliver comphrehensive RMNCAH services using PHC funds - Conduct a monitoring and evaluation framework to document lessons and best practices

comment.narrative: Funds to initiate this activity have not yet been received in the country. However some discussions have started to develop a concept note.

target.value: Support reduction of zero dose and under immunized children by 20% in 15 rural districts with high numbers of zero dose - Engage HSIP to develop an e registry for routine immunization - Engage a CSO to undertake the district support - Identify districts through data analysis including triangulation for districts with >2000 zero dose children for past 3 years - Map the areas with high numbers - Develop an evidence based strategic plan to reach the children through consultative workshops at district level - Support districts to deliver comphrehensive RMNCAH services using PHC funds - Conduct a monitoring and evaluation framework to document lessons and best practices

comment.narrative: The Ministry of Health suggested that WHO works together with the Smart Paper Technology (SPT) to undertake an e-registry of the immunization data and map areas with high numbers of zero dose. Due to competing activities by SPT which is currently rolling out into 10 districts, this has been delayed but will be focus in the first quarter of 2022

title.narrative: Service delivery approach suitable to reach missed communities identified and endorsed

target.value: Support reduction of zero dose and under immunized children by 20% in 15 rural districts with high numbers of zero dose - Engage HSIP to develop an e registry for routine immunization - Engage a CSO to undertake the district support - Identify districts through data analysis including triangulation for districts with >2000 zero dose children for past 3 years - Map the areas with high numbers - Develop an evidence based strategic plan to reach the children through consultative workshops at district level - Support districts to deliver comphrehensive RMNCAH services using PHC funds - Conduct a monitoring and evaluation framework to document lessons and best practices

comment.narrative: Initiated discussions with SPT since they are engaged with working with UNEPI in electronic capture of immunization Data. This has been delayed due to competing activities especially in regards to COVID-19

title.narrative: UNICEF : Demand Promotion & ACSM
Communication and social mobilization strategy developed

target.value: Engagement of health and non-health government extension workers/ structures (e.g. parish and sub county chiefs, teachers, CDOs etc.) to support EPI Comms and strengthen routine immunisation. i) Orientation, action planning and review meetings with DHO, DHE and district leadership to appreciate the need to prioritise EPI Comms. with a focus on RI, HPV and Td (zoom meeting, no funds for physical meeting done virtually led by the consultant)

comment.narrative: A C4D EPI consultant was hired to support the Ministry of Health, Health Promotion Department and UNEPI division. The consultant?s key deliverables included the engagement of health and non-health stakeholders to promote EPI services and increase demand/uptake for routine immunisation. A stakeholder engagement plan was developed to engage both health and non-health stakeholders. In Busoga region, 8 districts were engaged, and technical support provided on EPI Communication and development of action plans and review meetings. A total of 148 health stakeholders (DHT members, Health Facility staff, Health workers and VHTs) and 200 non-health stakeholders (CDOs, LC1s, Parents/Caregivers) were engaged. In central region, 7 districts were engaged, and technical support provided on EPI Communication and development of action plans. A total of 155 health stakeholders (DHT members, Health Facility staff, Health workers and VHTs) and 32 non-health stakeholders (CDOs, LC1s, Community Leaders, Parents/Caregivers) were engaged. The consultant also provided technical support to 9 of the 14 Regional Referral Community Health Departments in Advocacy, Communication and Social Mobilisation (ACSM). These included: Masaka, Jinja, Arua, Soroti, Naguru, Gulu, Lira, Mbale and Kabale where participants were oriented on the key EPI ACSM issues including demand generation issues during service delivery which demotivate parents and caregivers, the lack of IPC skills and the attitude of health workers when providing services.

title.narrative: Multi-media campaign on Routine and HPV Immunsiation, ICHDs implemented

target.value: Strengthen the advocacy, communication and social mobilization to maximise 'reach' of zero dose and under immunised target population in urban settings and rural communities through: i) Improving mobilisation, awareness and demand for immunisation through airing of multimedia campaigns (in 2 quarters) for Routine and HPV immunisation including April and October ICHDs. ii) Dissemination of the Urban Immunisation Communication Plan to improve demand and uptake for routine imunisation services in urban settings (zoom meeting, no funds for physical meeting done virtually led by the consultant)

comment.narrative: Mobilisation and awareness at community level for routine immunisation was mainly supported during the October ICHDs through radio, U-Report and social media. Through U-Report 531,436 U-Reporters were engaged. A total of 36,750 U-Reporters nationally consented to receiving ICHDs informational messages throughout the month of October. A series of 08 Informational messages, 04 feedback questions were sent out to U-Reporters to get the general feel about the exercise. 98% of the U-Reporters who responded to the initial message were interested in receiving more information about ICHDs. 65% of U-Reporters reported to be aware/heard of the ICHDs. When asked how they heard about ICHD, the majority, 35%, indicated Radio followed by through U-Report (39%), VHT or Health worker (17%) and 6% through social media. Overall, 58% of U-Reporters received or knew someone who received ICHD services during the month of October. When asked about services that were being offered, the majority indicated immunisation, vaccination followed by deworming and Polio. Through UNICEF social media platforms (Instagram and Twitter) we were able to reach 111,215 people. Radio spots for ICHDs were aired on 27 radio stations.

title.narrative: Progress report on implementation of the Urban Health Communication Strategy and registration of VHTs and children

target.value: Strengthen the advocacy, communication and social mobilization to maximise 'reach' of target population in urban settings through: 1) Development and finalisation of Urban Health communication guideline and implementation plan 2) Implement the urban immunisation communication plan through: Targeted information dissemination, dialogues/meetings with urban elites, informal settlements, refugees, schools, working caretakers 3) Scale up demand generation through registration of VHTs, Registration of children in municipalities, mobilisation & awareness at community level, address vaccine hesitancy and immunisation refusals

comment.narrative: The Urban Immunisation Communication Plan was made to maximize 'reach' of target population in urban settings. The plan provides a framework for action and connects and mobilizes partners and stakeholders in immunisation around a common cause. The plan aims to bring change among individuals, communities, social networks, and policy makers who will be connected through participatory activities and dialogue to participate in demand generation activities. To gather evidence to inform development of this plan, a rapid assessment was conducted in 7 districts of Kampala, Wakiso, Mukono, Jinja, Iganga, Gulu and Mbarara. targeting 17 urban settings in densely populated informal settlements and high-end social class communities. The draft plan is undergoing finalization reviews before dissemination, planned for August 2021. Despite the challenges associated with the Corvid 19 pandemic, the 12 districts that implemented the registration of VHTs and children were followed up to review district continuity plans, assess progress in implementation and propose strategies for increasing child registration to improve RI services. Community mobilisation was enhanced during the April CHDs and AVW through radio, U-Report and social media. U-Report engaged 512,629 U-Reporters. Overall,136,974 responses and comments were received. 70% of U-Reporters received or knew someone who received CHD services.. To address vaccine hesitancy and immunisation refusals, opportunities to engage with the district health educators (DHE) included: - virtual training in preparation for the Corvid 19 vaccine introduction. The second engagement was during the training of Regional Referral Hospitals supervision teams that included all the DHEs. Mapping of religious groups/cults and resistant communities to address vaccine hesitancy and immunisation refusals done in Jinja, Mukono, Iganga and Kampala and Arua. Moving forward, DHEs have developed action plans to address identified obstacles.

target.value: Strengthen the advocacy, communication and social mobilization to maximise 'reach' of target population in urban settings through: 1) Development and finalisation of Urban Health communication guideline and implementation plan 2) Implement the urban immunisation communication plan through: Targeted information dissemination, dialogues/meetings with urban elites, informal settlements, refugees, schools, working caretakers 3) Scale up demand generation through registration of VHTs, Registration of children in municipalities, mobilisation & awareness at community level, address vaccine hesitancy and immunisation refusals

comment.narrative: The Urban Immunisation Communication Plan was made to maximize 'reach' of target population in urban settings. The plan provides a framework for action and connects and mobilizes partners and stakeholders in immunisation around a common cause. The plan aims to bring change among individuals, communities, social networks, and policy makers who will be connected through participatory activities and dialogue to participate in demand generation activities. To gather evidence to inform development of this plan, a rapid assessment was conducted in 7 districts of Kampala, Wakiso, Mukono, Jinja, Iganga, Gulu and Mbarara. targeting 17 urban settings in densely populated informal settlements and high-end social class communities. The draft plan is undergoing finalization reviews before dissemination, planned for August 2021. Despite the challenges associated with the Corvid 19 pandemic, the 12 districts that implemented the registration of VHTs and children were followed up to review district continuity plans, assess progress in implementation and propose strategies for increasing child registration to improve RI services. Community mobilisation was enhanced during the April CHDs and AVW through radio, U-Report and social media. U-Report engaged 512,629 U-Reporters. Overall,136,974 responses and comments were received. 70% of U-Reporters received or knew someone who received CHD services.. To address vaccine hesitancy and immunisation refusals, opportunities to engage with the district health educators (DHE) included: - virtual training in preparation for the Corvid 19 vaccine introduction. The second engagement was during the training of Regional Referral Hospitals supervision teams that included all the DHEs. Mapping of religious groups/cults and resistant communities to address vaccine hesitancy and immunisation refusals done in Jinja, Mukono, Iganga and Kampala and Arua. Moving forward, DHEs have developed action plans to address identified obstacles.

title.narrative: Urban communication guidelines and implementation plan finalized and disseminated in 4 urban districts (Kampala, Wakiso, Jinja and Iganga

target.value: Strengthen the advocacy, communication and social mobilization to maximise 'reach' of target population in urban settings through: 1) Development and finalisation of Urban Health communication guideline and implementation plan 2) Implement the urban immunisation communication plan through: Targeted information dissemination, dialogues/meetings with urban elites, informal settlements, refugees, schools, working caretakers 3) Scale up demand generation through registration of VHTs, Registration of children in municipalities, mobilisation & awareness at community level, address vaccine hesitancy and immunisation refusals

comment.narrative: The urban communication guidelines and plan has been developed and is currently being reviewed by MOH. Plans are underway to print the plan as soon as it is signed off and this will be followed with the implementation during August to October period. The consultant who developed the plan will continue with the implementation. The slow implementation has been due to Corvid 19 pandemic.

title.narrative: 14 regional champions advocating,creating awarness drives and mobilising for immunisation; social media plan developed and implemented; reports from the non-health stakeholder meetings in 22 districts; Monitoring reports, reach and coverage analysis of the Radio campaign

target.value: Support Advocacy, Social Mobilisation and Communication through engagement of decision makers at national, district and community level to improve immunisation coverage: 1) Engagement and Linking of 14 regional champions and decision makers to support immunisation (Professional associations will be engaged -UPA, UMA, AUWD)? 2) Support the professional association develop and implement a Social media plan to support RI and HPV specifically, human interest stories (national and district level) (Professional associations will be engaged -UPA, UMA, AUWD)? 3)Provide technical support to the 14 regional Community health departments in advocacy, social mobilisation and communication 4) Improving mobilisation, awareness and demand for immunisation through Airing of comprehensive media messages and radio talk show appearances 2 quarters for routine and HPV immunisation covering including April and October ICHD.

comment.narrative: UNICEF Uganda has initiated a process to engage Uganda Pediatric Association (UPA) to support at national and district level with a special focus on urban districts to address immunisation inequities The expected outputs include strengthened capacity of Regional Referral Hospital Community Health Departments to plan and implement ACSM interventions to promote routine immunisation; institute regional champions and decision makers to advocate for and promote Routine immunisation; and sensitizing and supporting members of Uganda Medical Association, Uganda Paediatric Association, Uganda Nurses, Midwife and Public Health cadres and associations to actively get involved in media and community mobilisation efforts for routine immunisation (linked to supporting Urban Immunisation) The UPA engagement has delayed. The bottleneck has been identified and redress is underway. Improving mobilisation, awareness and demand for immunisation through airing of comprehensive media messages on radio, social media and through U-Report are ongoing. U-Report engaged 512,629 U-Reporters. Overall,136,974 responses and comments were received. 70% of U-Reporters received or knew someone who received CHD services. Through UNICEF social media platforms (Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter) we were able to reach 36,182 people. Media engagement during the April child health days and the events to mark the Africa vaccination week

title.narrative: PATH : Vaccine-Specific Support
Participation in continued school and facility level review meetings completed

target.value: Technical support to MOH to monitor HPV Coverage Improvement Plan (CIP) implementation progress, identify challenges, propose solutions

comment.narrative: Coverage improvement completed with MOH. Reports of work are attached to other milestones.

title.narrative: Support provided to schools and health facilities to address gaps in planning and implementation

target.value: Conduct school and health facility supportive supervision in Kampala & Wakiso

comment.narrative: PATH engaged immunization teams to use onsite service points for example family planning clinics, OPD (out patient department) for vaccination in addition to community mobilization for the girls that missed first or second dose using VHTs (Village Health Teams). This was part of the MOHs immunization recovery plan. This has been an ongoing intervention in 2021 especially in Kampala, coverage for HPV has been persistently low.

target.value: Nat?l TWG meetings and continued support for program refresh

comment.narrative: PATH participated in the district and national TWG meetings.

Participation in district MOE support completed

comment.narrative: PATH engaged the Department of Education together with Department of health. However, this was not maximally done because schools were under lockdown. PATH met with DEOs and District Medical Team to prepare for massive immunization when children eventually come back to school.

target.value: Ongoing quarterly district review and learning meetings (15 targeted districts) to monitor program and coverage improvements

comment.narrative: PATH supported the stakeholders meeting and provided supervision in April and May 2021.

title.narrative: Develop key messages, circulars, flyers with key messages targeting parents, school authorities, and leaders

target.value: Support for improved social mobilization for HPV uptake

comment.narrative: Social mobilization through Radio and TV Talk- shows using pioneers of HPV to improve public trust and uptake of the vaccine by sharing evidence that taking HPV did not stop girls from producing children.

title.narrative: Support to convene and facilitate performance review workshops for HPV and immunization at division level with key stakeholders

target.value: Ongoing quarterly review meetings to monitor performance at division level (Kampala & Wakiso)

comment.narrative: Two engagements were done, in April and May. Private sector providers in Wakiso and Kampala were brought on board.

title.narrative: UNICEF : Service Delivery
Service delivery related barriers of missed communities to access immunisation services identified and prioritized

target.value: Provide technical and financial support to selected poor perfoming(zero dose and underimmunised) and hard to reach districts through: i) Conduct supervision, mentorship and monitoring ii) Perfomance review meetings in selected poorly perfoming regions (zero dose and underimmunised) to discuss, identify, implement and monitor sustainable interventions to reach zero dose children and reduction of missed opportunities

comment.narrative: The 61 districts identified with large numbers 'Zero dose' and 'Under immunised' children, constitute 51% of the national target population with 241,755 zero dose and 184,150 under immunised children from 2018-2020 data. In 2021, RED/REC consultants support contributed to 6 percent reduction as compared to 2020 (55,857 zero dose and 39,201 under immunised). By September 2021, more than 40% of the 61 priority districts registered remarkable improvement in reducing the unreached children. The main areas of intervention were: 1) Technical support, capacity building, supervision, and mentorship for 2095 HWs covering 996 (48%) of the targeted health facilities; 2) Developing/updating FY 2021/2022 immunization micro plans to include identified inequities, actions to increase reach and required budget estimates; and 3) Performance review meetings focusing on monitoring of zero doze and under immunized children. Teams were empowered to smoothen out their work processes and innovation mainly in planning and data utilization at source. To improve equity and access to immunisation through Effective Vaccine Management in all the 136 districts, UNICEF worked with MOH/UNEPI and NMS and held a meeting for the Assistant District Health Officers, District Cold Chain Technicians and Biostatisticians. The meetings created strong teamwork among the officers that should improve Vaccine Management data quality and reporting on the EVM KPIs. 398 district officers were oriented on EVM KPI, problems identified and solutions for improvement. The meeting recommended better/proper usage of EPI assets, recruitment to fill up vacant posts.

title.narrative: WHO : Leadership, management, and coordination (LMC)
Tools and mechanisms to assess and monitor quality and acceptance of services developed and in use by countries

target.value: Support functionality of Uganda National Technical Advisory Immunization Group of experts and regional Immunization supervision teams

comment.narrative: Sub working committees were established to review the questions at hand and 10 meetings were held. Two broad UNITAG meetings were also conducted; Capacity building efforts of selected members of UNITAG were also conducted; Due to COVID-19 pandemic several working groups have also been established to review service delivery within the context of the pandemic and also a COVID-19 vaccine working group. Regarding regional immunization teams ; trainings for the four regions were conducted; A total of 120 RISMT participants were trained; Participatory teaching and learning methods were used which included active participation through brain storming, smaller group discussion, case studies, question and answer sessions, demonstration and return demonstration

title.narrative: Tools and approaches developed to improve and sustain quality and safety of immunisation services

target.value: Support functionality of Uganda National Technical Advisory Immunization Group of experts and regional Immunization supervision teams

comment.narrative: The NITAG has been supported technically , since they are now receiving funding directly from GAVI. They however have submitted a protocol for research which WHO will be supported next year

title.narrative: WHO : Health Information Systems (Data)
100% (4813) of 4813 health facilities staff received skills and knowledge on AEFI reporting, management and investigation

target.value: Conduct in service training to roll out the vaccine Pharmacovigilance at the HF level including VAEMIS with close collaboration with NDA

comment.narrative: The master TOT was expanded to 24 from seven who had earlier been trained; The TOT was immediately deployed to the selected districts to conduct a one day deep dive mentorship/training of the health workers including DHT; The number of health workers trained by level were 293 DHTs, 168 health workers from hospitals, 225 health workers from HCIVs, 871 health workers from HCIII, 977 health workers from HCII and 53 health workers from other health facilities were trained. In total 2,591 health workers were trained. from 44 districts. The biggest challenge was inadequate financial resources to cover more districts

target.value: Conduct in service training to roll out the vaccine Pharmacovigilance at the HF level including VAEMIS with close collaboration with NDA

comment.narrative: The master TOT was expanded to 24 from seven who had earlier been trained; The TOT was immediately deployed to the selected districts to conduct a one day deep dive mentorship/training of the health workers including DHT; The number of health workers trained by level were 293 DHTs, 168 health workers from hospitals, 225 health workers from HCIVs, 871 health workers from HCIII, 977 health workers from HCII and 53 health workers from other health facilities were trained. In total 2,591 health workers were trained. from 44 districts. The biggest challenge was inadequate financial resources to cover more districts

title.narrative: WHO : Programme Management - General
Twelve (12) of the planned monthly subcomittees on data/surveillance, Programme management and service delivery scheduled and conducted at the national level

target.value: Provide technical support to the monthly EPI sub committees of Data/Surveillance, Program management and service delivery

comment.narrative: The routine planned monthly meetings conducted were four; however following the need to roll out COVID-19 vaccine these were adjusted to weekly and later during implementation to daily with the main focus on COVID-19 vaccine; review of surveillance and routine immunization data was integrated within the EPI technical meetings. Biggest challenge was competing priority to focus on rolling out COVID-19 vaccine data management tools with limited attention on having a deep dive on routine immunization data.

target.value: Provide technical support to the monthly EPI sub committees of Data/Surveillance, Program management and service delivery

comment.narrative: The routine planned monthly meetings conducted were four; however following the need to roll out COVID-19 vaccine these were adjusted to weekly and later during implementation to daily with the main focus on COVID-19 vaccine; review of surveillance and routine immunization data was integrated within the EPI technical meetings. Biggest challenge was competing priority to focus on rolling out COVID-19 vaccine data management tools with limited attention on having a deep dive on routine immunization data.

title.narrative: WHO : Data
Tools and mechanisms to assess and monitor quality and acceptance of services developed and in use by countries

target.value: Provide administrative support for top up allowance and provision of data bundles for teams at the surveilance sites to transmit data from the new vaccine sentinal sites to produce data that will monitor and evaluate new vaccine introduction ( Rota, PCV and Penta), and data analysis for timely use

comment.narrative: Monthly data from the four sentinel sites has been submitted on time; monthly site coordination meetings have been held; allowances for the teams have been paid; sites have been supplied with the laboratory supplies; awaiting for funds under TCA 2021 that the country has not yet received

target.value: Provide administrative support for top up allowance and provision of data bundles for teams at the surveilance sites to transmit data from the new vaccine sentinal sites to produce data that will monitor and evaluate new vaccine introduction ( Rota, PCV and Penta), and data analysis for timely use

comment.narrative: This activity has been undertaken and teams at the surveillance sites were supported with data bundles and top-up allowance

title.narrative: WHO : Human Resources for Health
Learning package for in-service training and performance management including supervision developed and tested

target.value: Support implementation of modified MLM in all districts and expansion of operational level training in 60 districts - Support adaptation of MLM training modules for online and physical workshops of DHT and OPL - Develop a roll out plan for MLM and OPL - Facilitate in selected workshops - conduct M and E of the MLM and OPL workshops

comment.narrative: The funds allocated to this activity were inadequate and hence there were reprogrammed towards other areas under human resource component who supported MOH to develop concept note for MLM; the HSS grant under MOH has resources to support the MLM training

title.narrative: Comprehensive in-service training and continuous professional education plans for vaccinators developed

target.value: Support implementation of modified MLM in all districts and expansion of operational level training in 60 districts - Support adaptation of MLM training modules for online and physical workshops of DHT and OPL - Develop a roll out plan for MLM and OPL - Facilitate in selected workshops - conduct M and E of the MLM and OPL workshops

comment.narrative: WHO has supported the Ministry of Health to revise and update the IIP manual. Also Regional Trainings of IIP has been undertaken. MLM training has been reprogrammed due to competing activities especially COVID-19

title.narrative: CDC : Health Financing/Sustainability
Costing study completed

target.value: Technical assistance to determine the cost effectiveness of different approaches to DTP booster dose introduction; school-based delivery, facility-based delivery, single cohort approach, and multiple cohort approach.

comment.narrative: "Reporting status: completed Progress: An initial costing study was completed in May 2021. Findings were shared with Ministry of Health (MoH) in small internal meeting (due to COVID-19 restrictions). MoH requested additional costing analysis which is currently being planned. "

title.narrative: Final report on study findings.

target.value: Continue technical assistance to determine the cost and cost effectiveness of different approaches to DTP booster dose introduction; school-based delivery, facility-based delivery, single cohort approach, and multiple cohort approach. Includes dissemination of the findings.

comment.narrative: "1. Major Delays 2. DTP booster dose costing: phase 1 completed, phase 2 in progress with report to be available in early 2022. DTP booster dose modeling: development of model has commenced, Gavi represented on the expert reference group; results from first use in Uganda estimated to be available later in 2022. "

target.value: Continue technical assistance to determine the cost and cost effectiveness of different approaches to DTP booster dose introduction; school-based delivery, facility-based delivery, single cohort approach, and multiple cohort approach. Includes dissemination of the findings.

comment.narrative: "Reporting status: major delays Progress: Health and economic effects of DTP booster dose introduction not yet completed. Modeling group has been identified though there have been delays with finalizing the contract due to the time taken for contract negociations with the institution. All parties are aware of the delay and actively working to finalize contract so the work can begin. Members for an expert reference group (incl. rep from Gavi) have been identified though formation of this group is awaiting pending contract approval. "

target.value: Continue technical assistance to determine the cost and cost effectiveness of different approaches to DTP booster dose introduction; school-based delivery, facility-based delivery, single cohort approach, and multiple cohort approach. Includes dissemination of the findings.

comment.narrative: "Reporting status: major delays Progress: Health and economic effects of DTP booster dose introduction not yet completed. Modeling group has been identified though there have been delays with finalizing the contract due to the time taken for contract negociations with the institution. All parties are aware of the delay and actively working to finalize contract so the work can begin. Members for an expert reference group (incl. rep from Gavi) have been identified though formation of this group is awaiting pending contract approval. "

title.narrative: Costing results to be presented at stakeholder consultation meeting that will inform country-level decisions about introduction of DTP booster doses.

target.value: Continue technical assistance to determine the cost and cost effectiveness of different approaches to DTP booster dose introduction; school-based delivery, facility-based delivery, single cohort approach, and multiple cohort approach. Includes dissemination of the findings.

comment.narrative: "Reporting status: on track Progress: Initial delays due to COVID-19. Additional costing analysis is being planned (per milestone reporting from 2019) with estimated timeline for completed three months from start of contract period. Results will be presented to Ministry of Health and immunziation stakeholders in Uganda once finalized. "
